metadata.subject: THE POWER OF NOTHING Could studying the placebo effect change the way we think about medicine?

organizations: Program in Placebo Studies and the Therapeutic Encounter
University of California at San Francisco
Walter Reed Army Institute of Research
Wayne State University School of Medicine

relationships.description: Kaptchuk is a professor and director at Harvard Medical School's Program in Placebo Studies

relationships.entity_2: Program in Placebo Studies and the Therapeutic Encounter
relationships.description: Kaptchuk was named director of the newly created institute
Franklin led a commission investigating Mesmer's claims of animal magnetism

analysis.purpose: To explore the scientific validity and potential clinical applications of the placebo effect through historical context and current research
analysis.significance: Examines a paradigm shift in medical thinking about the relationship between belief, expectation, and healing

notable_quotes: "I had great respect for shamans—and I still do. I have always believed there is an important component of medicine that involves suggestion, ritual, and belief—all ideas that make scientists scream."
"Placebos don't shrink tumors. They don't make blind people see. If you are paralyzed, they won't help you walk."

"Because I am a damn good healer. That is the difficult truth. If you needed help and you came to me, you would get better. Thousands of people have. Because, in the end, it isn't really about the needles. It's about the man."

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this scientific article

illegal_activity.description: This is a scientific journal article about placebo research with no illegal activity discussed

details: Article published in The New Yorker by Michael Specter
References to media coverage and scientific publications

public_knowledge.context: This is a published New Yorker article about placebo research, making it publicly available information

analysis.summary: This New Yorker article explores the scientific investigation of the placebo effect, focusing on Ted Kaptchuk's work at Harvard Medical School. It examines historical context, current research findings, and the ongoing debate about whether placebos could have legitimate clinical applications beyond their traditional use in drug trials.
